name: chat 20230613-125320-466753d4 - technology - China banned 23 million people - controversy

conversation.text: China banned 23 million people with poor social credit from transportation in 2018

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.
the fact they even have a social credit system is a problem that you can't explain away about different perspectives
what the fuck do you think the fico rating system is in america?

fico and the social credit system are two entirely different things, credit score is a basic financial concept of rating someones fiscal responsibility and trustworthiness, having a low credit score also does not limit you from any human rights and also havling a low credit score doesn't impact the people around you. you get a low social credit just for believing the wrong things or not being 100% supportive of the fucking dictatorship.

Just because a system seems like it is doing well in the us, does not mean it is Angela Merkel's fault. a system like social credit hasn't been well thought out and it could have a lot of negative consequences.

i believe that you are mistaken about this one because you are comparing the two systems, i believe that you need to try to see things from other people's point of view. it will teach you a lot about another culture to actually listen to what they are saying instead of judging them based on your own perspective.

conversation.text: China banned 23 million people with poor social credit from transportation in 2018

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.
the fact they even have a social credit system is a problem that you can't explain away about different perspectives
what the fuck do you think the fico rating system is in america?

fico and the social credit system are two entirely different things, credit score is a basic financial concept of rating someones fiscal responsibility and trustworthiness, having a low credit score also does not limit you from any human rights and also havling a low credit score doesn't impact the people around you. you get a low social credit just for believing the wrong things or not being 100% supportive of the fucking dictatorship.
having a low credit score also does not limit you from any human rights hilarious post

so basically don't just eat red meat, but a balanced diet. this is common sense. we will probably get a couple vegetarians using this as justification to eat no meat while they excuse away their achne/rashes and chronic constipation. /shrug

justification to eat no meat while they excuse away their achne/rashes and chronic constipationvegan for 2.5 years, and trust me, being vegan does not cause acne, rashes, or constipation. in fact, meat and dairy can *worsen* acne, and since vegan diets tend to have more fiber, they do the exact opposite of causing constipation.

since vegan diets tend to have more fiber, they do the exact opposite of causing constipation.fiber actually causes constipation. did you know most fiber is undigestable, and since we don't have a ruminant, we can't ferment it like say a cow? undigestable matter in your digestive track isn't good. definitely causes traffic jams. it's pretty simple.#x200b;in fact, meat and dairy can *worsen* acne,in 99% of cases, only dairy can. meat is what humans are most genetically adapted to consume, and doesn't contain all the endogenous plant pesticides that plants do (lectins, oxalates, etc), that over time compound and cause people serious issues.

fiber actually causes constipation. did you know most fiber is undigestable, and since we don't have a ruminant, we can't ferment it like say a cow? undigestable matter in your digestive track isn't good. definitely causes traffic jams. it's pretty simple.that’s not how it works. generally, when you’re constipated, you’re supposed to eat more fiber because most people actually don’t get enough fiber in their diets (average american gets 15g fiber every day; women under age 51 are supposed to get 25g and men under age 51 are supposed to get 38g daily). the additional fiber helps the poop pass through your digestive system faster. also, i poop like 4-5 times a day. believe me, i have absolutely no issues with constipation. eat is what humans are most genetically adapted to consume, and doesn't contain all the endogenous plant pesticides that plants do (lectins, oxalates, etc), that over time compound and cause most people serious issues.the academy of nutrition and dietetics and the british dietetic association agree that vegan diets are perfectly healthy. not sure where you’re getting this “most genetically adapted” thing.

that’s not how it works. generally, when you’re constipated, you’re supposed to eat more fiber because most people actually don’t get enough fiber in their dietsno, that's exactly how it works. fiber isn't a requirement. your body requires 0, and works better if you consume none. what these recommendations are based on is weak epidemiology. people who eat x amount of fiber a day are less likely to get x. the reason the people consuming larger amounts of undigestable crap can be statistically modeled as healthier, is because fiber, since you literally cant digest it (hence the constipation), slows your digestion, and thus the absorption of glucose and secretion of massive amounts of insulin, which we know when chronically elevated is a primary driver in most modern disease. it's very weak and dishonest 'science'we have lots of whacky guidelines. the ada tells diabetes to eat tons of carbohydrates, when all the science says they need to do the opposite to put their condition into remission, and avoid further negative consequences. british dietetic association agree that vegan diets are perfectly healthygermany determined otherwisenot sure where you’re getting this “most genetically adapted” thing.human evolution, and biochemistry. one simple example: vitamins and minerals in meat are the most bioavailable to us, and do not require conversion. vitamins and minerals in plants, are typically very poorly absorbed or require conversion to be usable.

no, that's exactly how it works. fiber isn't a requirement. your body requires 0, and works better if you consume none. what these recommendations are based on is weak epidemiology. people who eat x amount of fiber a day are less likely to get x. the reason the people consuming larger amounts of undigestable crap can be statistically modeled as healthier, is because fiber, since you literally cant digest it (hence the constipation), slows your digestion, and thus the absorption of glucose and secretion of massive amounts of insulin, which we know when chronically elevated is a primary driver in most modern disease. it's very weak and dishonest 'science'i’m going to rely on the scientific capabilities of actual experts and not some random person, thanks. fiber adds bulk to your stool, which moves it through your digestive system faster. germany determined otherwisetheir position was “if you’re vegan, you’d have to make sure you take a b12 supplement and get all the right nutrients. therefore you shouldn’t be vegan.” not exactly sound logic when you can literally just take a b12 supplement and make sure you get the right nutrients. human evolution, and biochemistry. one simple example: vitamins and minerals in meat are the most bioavailable to us, and do not require conversion. vitamins and minerals in plants, are typically very poorly absorbed or require conversion to be usable.but we can be perfectly healthy on vegan diets, so “poorly absorption” and “requiring conversion to be usable” clearly aren’t major issues.

i’m going to rely on the scientific capabilities of actual experts you don't know who i am or what i do. also, you should get interested in real mechanistic data, and not incredibly weak epidemiology and confounded data that even the simplest amount of logic is able to dispell. not doing so is going to harm you in the long run.their position was “if you’re vegan, you’d have to make sure you take a b12 supplement and get all the right nutrients. therefore you shouldn’t be vegan.” not exactly sound logic when you can literally just take a b12 supplement and make sure you get the right nutrients.there are compounds in animals foods we don't even know exist. some less known ones, that are vital to processes in homosapiens are carnitine, carnisone. a diet requiring supplementation of essential nutrients to even survive, not to mention thrive, is clearly a poor diet and not species appropriate.but we can be perfectly healthy on vegan diets, so “poorly absorption” and “requiring conversion to be usable” clearly aren’t major issues.for periods of time, sure. luckily the body is incredibly robust, and we have processes to deal with lack of nutrients, and poor conversion because it's how we survived during times of famine. without those backup capabilities we wouldn't be here. relying on inefficient backups systems is however asking for serious trouble over time.

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.

conversation.text: China banned 23 million people with poor social credit from transportation in 2018

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.

conversation.text: China banned 23 million people with poor social credit from transportation in 2018

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.

conversation.text: China banned 23 million people with poor social credit from transportation in 2018

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.
the fact they even have a social credit system is a problem that you can't explain away about different perspectives
what the fuck do you think the fico rating system is in america?

fico and the social credit system are two entirely different things, credit score is a basic financial concept of rating someones fiscal responsibility and trustworthiness, having a low credit score also does not limit you from any human rights and also havling a low credit score doesn't impact the people around you. you get a low social credit just for believing the wrong things or not being 100% supportive of the fucking dictatorship.
having a low credit score also does not limit you from any human rights hilarious post
i'm sorry, buying a car or even owning a house is not a fundamental human right. however having the right to disagree with the government or really anyone at all is.

pretty stupid to judge a collectivist nation as an individualist westerner with an entirely different upbringing but, i guess that is the american way. spread your democracy homie, at all costs, disregard everyone elses viewponts, no matter how well it works for them, something you will never understand

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.
the fact they even have a social credit system is a problem that you can't explain away about different perspectives

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.

conversation.text: China banned 23 million people with poor social credit from transportation in 2018

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.
the fact they even have a social credit system is a problem that you can't explain away about different perspectives
what the fuck do you think the fico rating system is in america?

fico and the social credit system are two entirely different things, credit score is a basic financial concept of rating someones fiscal responsibility and trustworthiness, having a low credit score also does not limit you from any human rights and also havling a low credit score doesn't impact the people around you. you get a low social credit just for believing the wrong things or not being 100% supportive of the fucking dictatorship.
having a low credit score also does not limit you from any human rights hilarious post
i'm sorry, buying a car or even owning a house is not a fundamental human right. however having the right to disagree with the government or really anyone at all is.

pretty stupid to judge a collectivist nation as an individualist westerner with an entirely different upbringing but, i guess that is the american way. spread your democracy homie, at all costs, disregard everyone elses viewponts, no matter how well it works for them, something you will never understand

id: chat20230614-071449-466753d4 - technology - China banned 23 million people-195
name: chat 20230614-071449-466753d4 - technology - China banned 23 million people - controversy

conversation.text: China banned 23 million people with poor social credit from transportation in 2018

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.

conversation.text: China banned 23 million people with poor social credit from transportation in 2018

i know reddit has a pretty anti-china thing going on at the moment. so, i'm willing to give up some karma to give a different perspective.to start, reddit is a predominantly english website that is blocked in china. that's a pretty big hurdle to overcome for a chinese citizen, so there won't be many to give their opinion. most who post are expats, or keyboard warriors with a knife to grind.something most articles about social credit miss out on (either intentionally or not) is that the whole thing is pretty experimental right now. different cities and provinces are measuring different things, seeing what repercussions to implement, and the effects they have. basically, this isn't some haphazard project that was started without caring about the fallout. that being said, i'm almost positive that it will roll out nation wide, but just when and how hasn't been solved.the other thing to understand about china is the big gap between the world people were raised in and the modern world. in a short time, it's been transformed from a rural farming country to an economic powerhouse, with some of the most modern tech on earth. this happened to other countries like the us too, but it happened much more gradually. there are people in china today, who grew up without electricity or plumbing, who worked on a farm with methods that hadn't really changed in hundreds of years. and now, they're middle aged and living on the 50th floor of a skyscraper in a city of 10 million people.that's completely bonkers. the value system they were raised on is completely incompatible with modern society. and mao's reforms in the 50s and 70s didn't help produce kind, well-adjusted people either - where if you didn't push to the front of the line, grease the right palms, or know the right people, you may starve or have the crap beaten out of you.but back to social credit, do you really think somebody who grew up in a rural world will pick up their dog's poop unless there was some sort of downside from not doing so? or someone used to smoking their whole life wherever they want suddenly can't? i remember back when i was a kid, and my city banned smoking in bars, and what a shitshow that was. imagine it in a nation of 1.4 billion, where the large majority of males are smokers.there's some bad stuff in there for sure - like video games (old men not "getting it", which i'm sure we can all relate to), or punishing friends of those with poor credit (how you appear in society, or "face" is a big deal in asian cultures, so it doesn't surprise me that's there - it would probably be more effective as a deterrent than any fine). but for better or worse, this is china trying to "catch up" to modern values. which i think is a noble ambition, even if the current state is a bit concerning or needs some adjustment. i'd like to wait and see.
